subject: Re: [junit] Unit testing Exception classes
msgSnippet: ... What are you afraid might break here? Most of my exception classes are immutable value objects that don t care if they re passed null through the
messageBody:
novotique wrote:
> Hi all,
>
> I am wondering if there is any benefit from UNIT testing Exception
> classes (those that inherit Throwable or Exception) ? Should I have a
> test class just for testing each Exception class that I develop for my
> application?

What are you afraid might break here?

Most of my exception classes are immutable value objects that don't care
if they're passed null through the constructor, so there's nothing to
test that the compiler isn't already testing.

If, for example, an exception class were computing a complicated error
message or something, I'd like test-drive that.

> Usually I UNIT test other classes that use the Exceptions (both valid
> and invalid cases) by using "fail".

That's a different question altogether. The good news is that the
community has written a lot about that. Search the web. Read recipe 2.8
of _JUnit Recipes_. Try Google keywords "junit exceptions".

> I am interested to see if other developers found any benefits from
> UNIT testing their Exception classes. Perhaps there are best practices
> on how to develop and test exceptions in Java?

I find nothing special about exception classes that makes me test or
test-drive them differently from any other class.

Take care.
